title: What's the technique used by this teacher to solve ax+by=GCD(a,b)?
text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=di3OXhHMZmI

It starts at 6:16

I can't share image here, so take this link for image.

https://mathforums.com/proxy.php?image=https%3A%2F%2Flh4.googleusercontent.com%2FvXyHA4zg8R-jOWdHVkm7Q8IPcevrsZZSGiKMx08gNnBoCRtY_ElYpeUHKoSKYjpEn7-Y7H_3UkKsqeaHx58g7-RiRdsbNA79KXY6XTbO_9XvqKKZSAidxFT5FhXIqcLz02P8DtBbZJSRxixIFEj0ESs&hash=83f9286e92f414517d400a4793be7756

It's the part where he's pointing his hand in this picture. I didn't get it although it's pretty mechanical, so I'd like to learn that technique as this is really useful in RSA algorithm(rather than having to memorize some values). I've been searching for a method like that since I saw this problem(been months) but could not find a technique like that. And it was always about just do it rather having any mechanical method like this one. So, I want to learn this.

Or, if you have any other simple methods to solve this equation, please tell me

Do you've any forums recommendations for getting help like this? I don't want to ask in stackexchange at first as they are pain in the ass always removing.

title: The C++ Iceberg Meme
Ask HN: How much info should founders share with early stage employees?
text:
I'm the founder of a small 7 person startup in the fintech space.

Should I share info on upcoming behind-the-scenes partnerships, etc with employees to pump them up? Or is giving too much information counterproductive/risky if an employee leaves?
